title: Where is RK Narayanâ€™s Malgudi? It depends on whom you are asking
content:
â€œI am often asked, â€˜Where is Malgudi?â€™â€ writes RK Narayan in his introduction to short story collection Malgudi Days (1942). â€œAll I can say is that it is imaginary and not to be found on any map (although the University of Chicago Press has published a literary atlas with a map of India indicating the location of Malgudi.) If I explain that Malgudi is a small town in South India, I shall only be expressing a half-truth, for the characteristics of Malgudi seem to me universal.â€Narayan set 14 novels and numerous short stories in the place that has become a fascinating meeting point of the real and the unreal and the lived and the imagined for admirers and literary detectives. Over the years, writers and filmmakers have speculated on Malgudiâ€™s whereabouts, with theories ranging from Bengaluru to Agumbe, where Shankar Nag set his renowned television adaptation. A radical theory about Malgudi has been proposed by Kannada actor and director Rakshit Shetty. The under-production film Thugs of Malgudi is set in the pre-independence era and plays out in Shettyâ€™s vision of what Malgudi must have been like if it existed.â€œEveryone knows Malgudi is a village somewhere in south India,â€ Shetty told Scroll.in. â€œEveryone also knows that Malgudi is a fictitious place. With my film, Iâ€™m picking up real historical events and taking them into a fictitious place â€“ a good tool for a filmmaker to play around with the idea of the real and the unreal.â€But thugs in a gentle and unhurried place like Malgudi?â€œWhat is a good reference point for violence â€“ innocence,â€ Shetty said. â€œMalgudi is innocence.â€Thank you for the wishes Sir. Can't wait to finish ASN and start working on #Thugs Script â˜ºï¸ğŸ¤— https://t.co/f0MeerGKILâ€” Rakshit Shetty (@rakshitshetty) May 4, 2017
The theories, myths and detective stories that surround Narayanâ€™s creation seem anything but innocent. In its own wicked ways, Malgudi continues to exercise the imagination, proving the power of Narayanâ€™s prose in making the fictional seem real.Depending on whom you choose to believe, Malgudi can be in Bengaluru or Mysuru, where monthly tours are conducted of the locations featured in Narayanâ€™s stories and Nagâ€™s TV series. In 2016, crime writer Zac Oâ€™Yeah claimed to have located Malgudi in Bengaluru. â€œ(In 1930) Narayan had just graduated and was unemployed, so he spent time with his grandmother who was in Bengaluru,â€ Oâ€™Yeah wrote in Conde Nast Traveller. â€œIn his autobiography he describes wandering about the streets, dreaming, planning, and then buying an exercise book in which he wrote the first line of a novel. â€˜As I sat in a room nibbling at my pen and wondering what to write, Malgudi with its little railway station swam into view, all ready-made, with a character called Swaminathan running down the platform,â€™ he writes. The station had a banyan tree, a station master, and two trains a day, one coming, one going.â€™â€RK Narayan.Bengaluru residents who retain memories of the old Malleswaram railway station believe he was referring to this very location. The balloon that Malgudi is a fusion of the names of two of Bengaluruâ€™s oldest localities, Malleswaram and BasavangudiÂ¸ still floats over the Karnataka capital.However, the inescapable fact is that Narayan spent most of his life in Myrusu. â€œThe Malgudi map drawn by Clarice Borio and reproduced on Narayanâ€™s request in one of his books, if tilted to the right, and then a bit to the left, bears a striking resemblance to a map of Mysore,â€ Oâ€™Yeah writes.The museum dedicated to the writer is located not in Bengaluru but on Vivekananda Road in Mysuru. The RK Narayan House is where the author lived and wrote most of his novels. It includes Narayanâ€™s study, dining area, his medals, collection of books and clothes and coats.â€œThe family wanted to sell off the house,â€ recalled CG Betsurmath, who was the Commissioner of the Mysore Corporation in 2015. â€œThere was a lot of public outcry, which forced the government to step in and preserve the place and re-imagine it as a conservation project. I was made in charge of the project and we asked the family to assemble in the house and tell us where what should be kept. We wanted to restore the house as it was when Narayan lived there.â€Where does Betsurmath think Malgudi could be? Mysuru, perhaps?â€œHow can it be in Mysuru?â€ Betsurmath countered. â€œMalgudi is in Malgudi. â€œDonâ€™t they show it in videos, in the TV show? Thatâ€™s where it is. Not in Mysore.â€Shankar Nag (left ) on the sets of Malgudi Days. Courtesy Manjunath.If Betsurmath believes Malgudi to be a real place, it has a great deal to do with Shankar Nagâ€™s vision. The polymath talent, who died in 1990 in an accident, breathed lives into the characters and locations in Narayanâ€™s stories in the vastly popular television series Malgudi Days. The series was aired on Doordarshan in 1986, and was shot in Agumbe near Shimoga in Karnataka. It has been telecast on Doordarshan numerous times, and is back on the national broadcaster on weekends at 8.30pm.The reasons for choosing Agumbe were simple: Nag was already a star in Kannada cinema, and needed a quiet place â€œwhere people would not go overboard with their adulationâ€, explained Arundhati Nag, the filmmakerâ€™s wife and actor and theatre personality. â€œThat whole belt from Shimoga to Teerthahalli to Agumbe â€“ the literacy levels are very high, so it was easy for us,â€ said Arundhati Nag, who was a part of the production team. â€œWeâ€™d sit in the backyard of peopleâ€™s homes and they wouldnâ€™t bother us. In fact, we had to beg people to come when we needed to shoot the crowd scene for Muniâ€™s wedding, for example.â€The topography of Agumbe appealed to Shankar Nagâ€™s conception of Malgudi. â€œThe two key streets in Agumbe fitted Shankarâ€™s idea of Malgudi,â€ Arundhati Nag said. â€œThe quaint houses there belonged to Malgudi. Also there were no electric poles in Agumbe at that time. So we could easily avoid them. Whenever we needed very urbanesque looking things â€“ obviously Agumbe did not have a college or a clock tower â€“ those he shot in Bangalore.â€


    
    Play

Malgudi Days.Even Shankar Nag knew that â€œMysore had a lot going for Malgudiâ€, added the Ranga Shankara theatre founder. â€œIf you look at the geography of Malgudi, you can actually plot it in Mysore,â€ Arundhati Nag said. â€œBut for us, it didnâ€™t make for good angles. Just trying to avoid modern structures and electrical lines would have been a nightmare. I guess taking a 100-member unit was only possible to Agumbe.â€A decision made for the sake of convenience has imprinted itself as Narayanâ€™s Malgudi in the minds of most fans of the Doordarshan series. â€œOur generation got to know of Malgudi not because of Narayanâ€™s books but Shankar Nagâ€™s series,â€ Rakshit Shetty said. â€œSo, Malgudi for us is always near Shimoga.â€Manjunath, the actor who played the role of the precocious child Swami in Nagâ€™s series, believes that Agumbe is Malgudi. â€œI donâ€™t want to read the books because I donâ€™t want any other version of Malgudi,â€ he said.Narayan approved of the series after a visit to the shoot of the episode based on his story Old man at the temple. â€œNarayan liked Shankarâ€™s treatment of the stories, he knew his stories were in safe hands,â€ Arundhati Nag said.Bengaluru, Mysuru, Agumbe â€“ the only consensus is that Malgudi is a South Indian town. â€œThose in Karnataka believe it is in their state and those in Tamil Nadu believe it is there because Narayan grew up in Madras,â€ said Bhuvaneshwari, RK Narayanâ€™s grand-daughter. â€œSome say it is on the border of the two states. It could be anywhere. I frankly donâ€™t know. He was never the kind to discuss these things at home. His writing was transparent and his English was simple. In his writing, he represented the life that he lived. Malgudi must be the product of his observations.â€Narayan was well aware of what he had unleashed by creating Malgudi. â€œMalgudi has been only a concept but has proved good enough for my purposes,â€ he wrote in the introduction to the short stories. â€œI canâ€™t make it more concrete, however much I might be interrogated.â€A few paragraphs later, Narayan writes about running into an enthusiastic TV producer in London who asked him to show him around Malgudi for his documentary feature. â€œI felt shaken for a moment and said out of politeness, â€˜I am going to be busy working on a new novel...â€™â€Set, no doubt, in Malgudi.
author: Archana Nathan
